Housing construction isn't very monosponous; there's generally a lot of construction companies in large areas like this, and housing construction is much more pay-as-you-go than a lot of other industries - the amount of capital costs you need to start up your own construction company aren't so bad compared to a lot of other industries. This makes this industry a lot more vulnerable to outside competition, which weakens its state as a monospony.
Thus I wouldn't expect construction to be particularly vulnerable to this relative to some other industries, especially not in the region described in the article. Anywhere with 72,000 construction workers is a pretty populated area. Monosponous unemployment is more likely to occur in areas where there are few employment options, rather than areas like this, where there are a lot of employment options.
If the competitive market wage to hire new workers is really $11/hour, then why haven't their construction workers abandoned ship already?
An additional issue lies in the fact that wages *are* increasing. As the article notes:
As the Dallas Morning News notes, between 2012 and 2016, wages for Texas construction workers rose 21.2 percent, compared with 12 percent for all construction jobs in the U.S.
Thus we're seeing wages going up for these people, which suggests that the monosponous wage stagnation being described in your post isn't happening here. In fact, wages are going up *faster* here than they are elsewhere.
It is also worth noting that housing prices are themselves increasing, which suggests that the marginal value of the labor is going up as well.
One plausible explanation is simply that there isn't a labor shortage at all - that the allegedly missing 18,000 construction workers simply don't exist. The perception of scarcity gives them a rationale for hiking prices on customers.
It is also possible that this may be just a repercussion of the pre-great recession construction boom, and there may yet be something of a glut of houses, reducing the demand for just generic "new houses", but people who are buying new houses are willing to pay a premium for the house *they* want. Thus the new housing market is confined to people who don't just want *a* house, they want a house with particular features which aren't available in the mass market.
I'm not sure how they're actually estimating that they're short 18,000 workers. Without knowing that, it is hard to say for sure.
But I'm suspicious of the argument that this is a result of monospony, because we're seeing above-average wage increases, which is the opposite of what we'd expect in such a situation. It seems likely to me that some other factor is in play here.

This sort of thing is inherently unsteady state. If you can raise prices, then you can hike wages and hire more people to build stuff at the new, higher prices you're getting and make more money.
You generally won't see this be persistent for any real length of time if it is possible to raise prices on consumers.
Thus, the situation will only really exist in two situations:
1) Consumers won't pay higher prices (i.e. they can wait), which makes paying higher wages impossible. This can happen if your customers are particularly price sensitive.
2) The situation is temporary, not permanent (i.e. the shortage is temporary/the surge in demand is temporary, but employees are likely to walk if you lower their wages back down after the surge in demand. Thus, even if you might be able to make money now by hiring more people and hiking wages, you'll lose money in the long term).
